unit: Unit 8 | Inference for Categorical Data: Chi-Square
title: Math Program: Null and Alternative Hypotheses
question_text:
Suppose a high school principal wishes to determine if students in her after-school math program perform better than those not in the program.
The principal randomly selected $115\text{ students}$ for an after-school study session that runs $3\text{ days per week}$ for $1\text{ hour}$ each day, focusing solely on math.
The grade distribution of these students’ math grades is compared to the historical grade distribution of students’ math grades at this high school. The data is below:
What are appropriate alternative and null hypotheses for this problem if the principal wishes to perform a chi-squared goodness of fit test?

solution:
Choices 'A' and 'B' are incorrect; chi-squared tests cannot give one-sided results.

Choice 'D' is incorrect; these would be the hypotheses for a one-proportion $Z$-test.

Choice 'E' is incorrect; there is only one variable (grades of those in the program) to compare to a historical average.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'C'.
